title: 106_hr1670
content: The "Presidential Commission to Study the Culture and Glorification of Violence in America Act" establishes a commission to study the culture and glorification of violence in America. The Commission's duties include examining the impact of violence in society. The Commission established by the "Presidential Commission to Study the Culture and Glorification of Violence in America Act" will examine the glorification of violence in the United States, the relationship between psychological stress and increased violence, the role of the media in today's violent atmosphere, the correlation between access to firearms and increased violence, the role of the school system in identifying potential perpetrators of violence, and make recommendations to address these issues. The Commission, composed of 22 members appointed by various leaders, must have special knowledge or experience in violence-related issues, including sociologists, psychologists, clergy, law enforcement officials, victims of violence, and media representatives. The Commission, consisting of 22 members with expertise in violence-related issues, must not consider political affiliation in appointments. Members serve for the Commission's duration, vacancies filled as per original appointment method. Members do not receive pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. Nine members form a quorum for Commission business. The Commission consists of 22 members with expertise in violence-related issues, who elect a Chairperson to hold hearings and conduct meetings as needed. The Chairperson has the authority to appoint and determine the pay of Commission personnel, who are subject to certain civil service laws. Additionally, the Commission can request personnel from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. The Commission also has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and receive information from government agencies to fulfill its duties. Members can delegate their authority, and the General Services Administrator provides administrative support services upon request. The Commission has the authority to contract with Government or private agencies for necessary supplies or services without following certain statutes. The Commission will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress within one year of all original members being appointed. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. Any spending authority authorized by this Act is subject to appropriations Acts.
